IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Exhibits: Please see the Attachments portion of this report for ALL documents/photos related to this investigation. Search and seizure warrant photographs were uploaded to VeriPic. Narrative: On January 9th, 2023, TFC Waldys Batista #6650, assigned to the Maryland State Police Criminal Enforcement Division, responded to 158 Caspian Drive, Grasonville, MD 21638 for a reported theft of firearms. Upon arrival, TFC Batista made contact with Troopers on scene and was immediately appraised of the situation. TFC Batista learned that on the evening of January 9th, 2023 the victim, Donald Allen Howard, was made aware that his checking account through PNC Bank was compromised. Mr. Howard then noticed his PNC debit card was missing from his wallet. Mr. Howard advised that Derek Tyler Hartman was in his residence on Friday, January 6th, 2023. Hartman is a handyman contracted by Mr. Howard with full access to the residence. On January 6th Hartman contacted Mr. Howard and advised he left a laptop computer in the residence that she needed to retrieve. Mr. Howard advised that Hartman entered his residence on January 6th and remained unsupervised on the first floor while he searched for the laptop. Mr. Howard believes that Hartman stole his debit card while at the residence on January 6th. The following fraudulent transactions were made on January 9th: Royal Jewelers- $1200 debit/ $1050 Cash (Annapolis) Footlocker- $333.89 Ardene Store- $44.90 ATM 161 Defense Hwy Annapolis, MD (Gas Station)- $400 ATM PNC Bank 303 Sail Pl Annapolis, MD- $800 ATM 1383 Main St Stevensville, MD (Gas Station)- $162 ATM 107 Dominion Rd Chester, MD (7Eleven)- $400 ATM PNC Bank 120 S. Piney RdChester, MD- $800 ATM PNC Bank 101 Hissey Rd Grasonville, MD- $500 ATM PNC Bank 101 Hissey Rd Grasonville, MD- $500 Retail Transaction Total: $1,578.79 ATM Transaction Total: $3,562.00 On January 9th, 2023, management personnel at Royal Jewelers provided still photos of Derek Hartman in the store purchasing various gold and diamond jewelry using an orange debit card. The debit card resembled the PNC debit card belonging to Donald Howard. Mr. Howard was able to positively identify Hartman from the photos as well as Hartmans girlfriend Ava Kurst. TFC Batista obtained receipts from Royal Jewelers which show that Hartman used Mr. Howards debit card to make the fraudulent transaction. The receipt showed the last 4 digits of the debit card which match Mr. Howards PNC card. When Mr. Howard learned that Derek Hartman stole his debit card and conducted fraudulent transaction, he looked over to his gun-room and noticed that a key was inserted into the lock. Mr. Howard advised that the gun-room is always locked and that he is the only person authorized to access the gun-room. Howard stated he did not touch the key but was able to make entry and observe that several of his long guns were missing. The following AR-15 style long guns were missing: One (1) Colt AR-15 Rifle 5.56 caliber (Serial# LE571721)- $10,000 One (1) Smith Wesson MP-15 rifle 5.56 caliber (Serial#SW51369)- $5,000 One (1) Uzi 9mm caliber (Serial# SA56415)-$2,500 One (1)One (1) AR-15 style pistol caliber .458 socom-(Serial#TE07175)-$2,100 Mr. Howard was able to provide an estimated value of the firearms to include any accessories such as scopes and or other attachments. The total value is estimated to be $19,600.On January 10th, 2023, three (3) out of the four (4) stolen firearms were entered into NCIC at the MSP Centreville Barracks. Later in the afternoon of January 10th, TFC Batista made contact with the victim who identified the fourth firearm as a Smith Wesson (MP 15) semi-automatic rifle cal. 450. The serial number associated with the rifle is TE07175 which was also entered as stolen into NCIC. Mr. Howard stated that prior to Friday, January 6th, 2023 there were no guns missing from his gun-room. He also stated that no one accessed the gun-room except for himself prior to that Friday. Mr. Howard stated he kept the keys to the gun-room in his office and stated that it is possible that Hartman saw here the keys are stored while at the residence. MSP Crime Scene Technician B. Demby arrived at the scene and processed the interior of the gun-room and exterior lock on the door. The keys were also swabbed for touch DNA. Fingerprint cards were also collected for future comparison. Electronic Surveillance/ Search Seizure Warrants After obtaining and verifying Hartmans cell phone number confirmed by Mr. Howard and other law enforcement databases, TFC Batista obtained a court ordered PEN Register to monitor Hartman and additional obtain historical data. The court order was signed on January 12th, 2023 by the Honorable Lynn Knight, Judge of the Circuit Court of Maryland in Queen Annes County. Investigators developed a pattern of life and obtained a location for Derek Hartman in Centreville, MD. On January 30th, 2023, Troopers and U.S. Marshals located Hartman at 624 Bradley Drive, Centreville, MD. He was arrested on outstanding theft and credit card fraud charges without incident. Shortly thereafter, a body warrant was executed on Hartman which yielded a yellow gold diamond bracelet with diamond letter D pendant which Hartman was wearing on his wrist and Adidas sneaker which are identical to the sneaker Hartman purchased at the Footlocker. Investigators also executed a warrant for Hartmans DNA and collected two (2) swabs containing his DNA sample. Both body and DNA warrants were signed by Judge Lynn Knight of the Queen Annes County Circuit Court on January 27th, 2023. Meanwhile, Investigators secured the apartment from which Hartman exited and subsequently arrested. On January 30th, 2023 at approximately 0840 hours Judge Lynn Knight reviewed and signed the search and seizure warrant. Inside the apartment, Investigators located and seized a cell phone on the couch where Hartman slept. The cell phone was identified as Hartmans cell phone by his roommates. All the aforementioned items recovered from the search and seizure warrant were seized and documented on the proper chain of custody forms. The DNA obtained from Hartman was sent to the MSP Forensic Science Division for testing and comparison. Hartmans cell phone was sent to the MSP Computer Lab for forensic extraction. On February 2nd, 2023, a separate search warrant for Hartmans cell phone was authored and signed by the Honorable Clara Campbell, a District Court Judge from Cecil County, MD. An additional supplement will be authored to document any data retrieved from the cell phone and/or the DNA results from the MSP laboratory. Case closed by arrest.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Additional Information: On January 30th, 2023, Investigators attempted to interview Derek Hartman pertaining to his involvement in the theft and fraud investigation associated with this case. Hartman was read his Miranda Rights and decided to invoke said rights. He was transported to the Commissioners Office in Queen Annes County, MD where he was held with bond pending a bail review hearing. This case remains closed by arrest

On 1/30/2023 I was assisting TFC Batista with this investigation. My involvement in this case included fingerprinting, and serving the arrest warrant for Derek Hartman. I have attached the signed copy of the arrest warrant to this supplement. After serving the warrant on Hartman, I transported him to the Queen Annes County Commissioners office. Hartman consulted with an attorney during the hearing and was ultimately held without bond. On 1/31/2023 Hartman had bail review and was continued to be held without bond. This concludes my involvement in the case

Exhibits: MSP Laboratory Report Narrative: On March 15, 2023, TFC Batista received the laboratory report from the Maryland State Police Forensic Science Division pertaining to the touch DNA samples collected from 158 Caspian Drive in Grasonville, MD. According to the report provided by MSP Forensic Scientist-Advanced Busch, the touch DNA testing results are inconclusive. The low level mixtures of the touch DNA are not enough to determine whether Derek Hartmans DNA sample was located on the wall hook or key that was processed by the crime scene technician. Case remains close.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeTitle: Supplement #5 Additional Details Related to Timeline
IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: On May 4, 2023, at approximately 1700 hours, TFC Batista made contact with Donald Howard in reference to additional clarification on the timeline that includes January 6 through January 9, 2023. Mr. Howard stated he believes Derek Hartman arrived at his residence on January 6, 2023, at approximately 1500 hours to retrieve a laptop belonging to his girlfriend Ava. Mr. Howard also stated there is a possibility that his firearms were stolen prior to January 6, 2023. Mr. Howard advised he checked his gun-room on different days during the month of December 2022 and observed that some firearms were missing. Mr. Howard did not recall the specific dates in December 2022 and did not advise why he did not conduct an inventory of his firearms. In addition, Mr. Howard did not advise why he did not report his firearms missing during the month of December 2022. Case remains closed.

On May 4th, 2023 at approximately 1630 hours, TFC made contact with Mr. Howard to obtain additional clarification of the timeline of events (see supplement #5). During the telephone conversation, Mr. Howard stated that on April 17, 2023 (Jury Trial for Derek Hartman) he had a meeting with the Queen Annes County States Attorney Lance Richardson regarding the criminal investigation. Mr. Howard advised, that during the meeting, he disclosed to Mr. Richardson that Derek Hartman made the following statement during a phone conversation on January 9, 2023: I felt like I was owed. This statement was made after Mr. Howard confronted Hartman about stealing the guns and committing fraud. Mr. Howard did not have an explanation as to why he did not disclose this information to TFC Batista earlier in the investigation and advised he simply forgot. Case remains closed.

On 6/21/2023 I contacted Derek Hartman at the Queen Annes County detention center where he was being held on a Violation of Probation arrest warrant. I was previously informed that he had requested that his phone be returned to him, and the States Attorney for Queen Annes County and the lead investigator for this case agreed that it could be returned. Hartman signed on the chain of custody document and a copy of that document was provided to him. Due to Hartman being incarcerated, the phone and chain of custody document for it were turned over to Correctional facility employees to be included with Hartmans other property. Scans of the evidence envelope and chain of custody have been attached to this supplement. This concluded my involvement in this case.
